Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election resulted in a virtual tie between the ruling party and the opposition (3,7). Voter turnout was high in the United States, with over 74% of eligible voters casting their ballots in the 2016 presidential election (8). Despite this, the results of the election did not break the deadlock in Macedonia (3,9). The conservative VMRO DPMNE party, led by former Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski, ultimately won 51 of 120 seats in parliament (4).

Timeline.Text: Security Message for U.S. Citizens warns of upcoming parliamentary elections in Macedonia.
Macedonia holds parliamentary elections with a chance to break a political deadlock.
The ruling conservative party narrowly wins the parliamentary elections in Macedonia.
Johan Tarculovski, a convicted Macedonian war criminal, is elected as an MP in the parliamentary elections.
A rerun vote in a tiny village secures victory for the conservatives in the Macedonian parliamentary elections.
Preliminary results show a 74.16% voter turnout in the 2016 United States presidential election.
Interesting facts about the United States of America are shared as the election approaches.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election (8) resulted in the victory of the ruling VMRO-DPMNE party led by ex-Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski (8). The new government formed after the elections, with Emil Dimitriev as the acting Prime Minister, focused on implementing security reforms (7). The European Commission Progress Report for Macedonia in 2016 served as a roadmap for the new government's activities (9). The World Bank praised Macedonia's efforts to improve the business climate (5). Johannes Hahn, the European Commissioner for Neighborhood Policy and Enlargement Negotiations, met with acting Prime Minister Emil Dimitriev to discuss the situation in the country after the elections (4). The State Election Commission handed out certificates to the elected MPs, including VMRO-DPMNE party and Social Democratic Union (3). A meeting between Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang and Macedonian Prime Minister Emil Dimitriev took place in November 2016 in Riga, where they discussed expanding cooperation (10).

Timeline.Text: Emil Dimitriev appears on a Facebook page for the VMRO Dpnm-Opila party.
Emil Dimitriev meets with the Greek Foreign Minister in August 2016.
Emil Dimitriev announces a comprehensive reform of security services.
Emil Dimitriev meets with World Bank executive director Frank Heemskerk and discusses efforts to improve the business climate in Macedonia.
Emil Dimitriev and EU Ambassador Samuel Zbogar discuss the 2016 European Commission Progress Report for Macedonia and its implications for future government activities.
Emil Dimitriev comments on the negotiations between winning political parties to form a new government.
Johannes Hahn meets with acting Prime Minister Emil Dimitriev to discuss the situation in Macedonia after the early parliamentary elections.
The newly elected MPs of Macedonia are given certificates by the State Election Commission.
Emil Dimitriev's ruling conservative party, VMRO-DPMNE, narrowly wins the parliamentary elections.
Emil Dimitriev meets with Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang and other Balkan leaders to discuss expanding cooperation.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election was a tightly contested affair, with the main parties being the VMRO-DPMNE led by former Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski and the Social Democrats led by Zoran Zaev (8). The election occurred two years early after Zaev revealed details about a large-scale wiretapping scandal (7). The election results were contested by Zaev, who filed a formal appeal with electoral authorities (4). However, President Gjorge Ivanov, nominated by the VMRO-DPMNE, has set conditions for giving the Prime Minister's mandate to Zaev or calling for a new election (6,10). The scandal also led to the dropping of all charges against Zaev by the Special Prosecution (5). The outcome of the election was a success for the opposition party, SDSM, who won over 50% more votes than in 2014 (9).

Timeline.Text: Zoran Zaev, leader of the opposition party SDSM, asks for support from farmers during a rally in Skopje.
Thousands gather at a leftist opposition rally in Macedonia.
Macedonia holds parliamentary elections, with the two main parties being VMRO-DPMNE, led by former prime minister Nikola Gruevski, and the pro-Western Social Democrats (SDSM), led by Zoran Zaev.
The State Election Commission announces that the conservative coalition led by Gruevski's VMRO-DPMNE has won the elections, narrowly defeating the SDSM.
The SDSM, led by Zoran Zaev, wins over 50% more votes than in the 2014 elections.
Zoran Zaev, leader of the opposition party SDSM, claims that the parliamentary elections were rigged and plans to appeal to electoral authorities.
Macedonia's Special Prosecution drops all charges against Zoran Zaev in the case known as 'Coup'.

The conservative coalition led by Gruevski's VMRO-DPMNE fails to form a coalition government, leaving the possibility of a new election or giving the mandate to the second-placed SDSM, led by Zoran Zaev.
President Gjorge Ivanov sets conditions for giving the mandate to form a government, including proof of a parliamentary majority.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election (10) took place on December 11 (1,2,5,9). The ruling party, VMRO-DPMNE, won a majority of the seats (4,7). Johan Tarculovski, a war crimes convict, was elected as a member of parliament for the VMRO-DPMNE party (2,8). However, the election was contested due to legal challenges (3).

Timeline.Text: Macedonia prepares for early parliamentary elections on December 11.
Macedonia holds early parliamentary elections, with both the ruling party and the main opposition claiming victory.
Macedonia's ruling party claims victory in the parliamentary election and its candidate, Johan Tarculovski, is elected as an MP.
Macedonian parliament speaker approves the decision to hold early general elections on December 11.
A small Macedonian party poses a legal challenge to the December 11 elections, citing the uneven size of electoral districts.
Johan Tarculovski, the only Macedonian convicted by the Hague war crimes tribunal, is nominated as a candidate in the parliamentary elections.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election was held on December 11 (4, 8, 10) after the parliament dissolved on October 17 (2, 6). The election was intended to end the country's long-running political crisis (5). The ruling party and largest opposition party both declared victory (10) and the conservative coalition led by ex-Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski won 38.06% of the vote (8). The election was preceded by several incidents of electoral fraud committed by the ruling coalition (3). President Gjorge Ivanov called on citizens to vote in the election (9).

Timeline.Text: Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov calls on citizens to vote in the upcoming parliamentary election on December 11.
The Macedonian parliament dissolves before the early election.
The political parties of Macedonia agree to hold the parliamentary election on December 11.
Macedonia's ruling party and opposition party both declare victory in the parliamentary election, resulting in a virtual tie.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election, also referred to as the 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election, took place on December 11 (1,3,5,9,10). The ruling party, VMRO-DPMNE, claimed victory with 51 seats out of 120 (1,3,9). However, the election was met with uncertainty and legal challenges (4,7). Controversially, the only Macedonian convicted by the Hague war crimes tribunal, Johan Tarculovski, was nominated as a candidate and later elected as an MP for VMRO-DPMNE (2,6). The election was seen as an attempt to resolve the country's long-running political crisis (10).

Timeline.Text: The ruling VMRO DPMNE party nominates Johan Tarculovski, a Macedonian war crimes convict, as a candidate for the parliamentary election on December 11.
The Macedonian parliament dissolves ahead of the upcoming parliamentary election on December 11.
A small Macedonian party files a motion to the Constitutional Court, challenging the legality of the upcoming parliamentary election due to the uneven size of the electoral districts.
Macedonia's ruling VMRO-DPMNE party and the Social Democratic Union (SDSM) both declare victory in the parliamentary election, which ends in a virtual tie.
The ruling VMRO-DPMNE party is declared the winner of the parliamentary election, securing 51 out of 120 seats.
The MPs elected in the parliamentary election on December 11 are given their certificates by the State Election Commission.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election (9) involved the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization - Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity (1,4,9). The election was held on December 11 (2,5,7) and resulted in a shake-up of the government (6). The ruling party, VMRO-DPMNE, failed to form a coalition with Albanian parties (4) and Austrian Foreign Minister Sebastian Kurz defended his decision to support the party (8). President Gjorge Ivanov gave the party a mandate to form a government (3). The legality of the election was contested by a small Macedonian party (2).

Timeline.Text: Early general elections are announced in Macedonia to determine the next prime minister.
The Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization – Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity (VMRO-DPMNE) wins the parliamentary election.
The VMRO-DPMNE fails to form a coalition with the Albanian parties, leading to a major shake-up in the government.
President Gjorge Ivanov demands proof of a parliamentary majority before giving any other party or alliance a mandate to form a government.
The political crisis in Macedonia continues after the latest elections.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election saw the ruling party VMRO-DPMNE win the elections and achieve 49 seats in the Assembly (2). However, the election commission ordered a re-run in one polling station due to complaints and pressure from supporters of the VMRO-DPMNE party (1,3). Despite this, the party's leader, former Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski, was given a mandate to form a new government (6). The party took an early lead in the election, with just under half the votes counted (8). The election was closely-fought and ultimately resulted in a fragile parliamentary majority for the conservatives (10).

Timeline.Text: The VMRO-DPMNE party is in the lead in the Macedonian parliamentary elections.
The governing conservatives, led by the VMRO-DPMNE, win the Macedonian parliamentary elections.
The leader of the VMRO-DPMNE, Nikola Gruevski, addresses the media after the election results are announced.
The election commission orders a re-run in one polling station.
Supporters of the VMRO-DPMNE party gather in front of the State Electoral Commission in Skopje to protest the handling of election complaints.
Johan Tarculovski, a convicted war criminal, is elected as an MP from the VMRO-DPMNE party.
Former PM Gruevski receives a mandate to form a new government, but must secure the support of ethnic Albanian parties.
The VMRO-DPMNE party admits failure in forming a coalition with the ethnic Albanian Democratic Union for Integration.
Austrian Foreign Minister Sebastian Kurz defends his decision to back the VMRO-DPMNE party in the upcoming elections.

Overview.Summary: The Macedonian parliamentary election of 2016 saw the dissolution of parliament and the appointment of a caretaker prime minister (2). The election also resulted in the election of Dimitar Kovachevski as the new prime minister of North Macedonia (3). However, the legality of the election was challenged due to uneven electoral districts (5). This election took place in the midst of a political crisis in the country (4,7,9), and was observed by international organizations such as the European Commission (8) and the Heinrich-Böll-Stiftung (10).

Emil Dimitriev is appointed as the acting Prime Minister of North Macedonia after the resignation of the previous Prime Minister.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election (9) resulted in the election of Johan Tarculovski from the main ruling VMRO DPMNE party as MP (1). It was held on December 11 (9) and featured a rematch between incumbent President John Dramani Mahama and his National Democratic Congress (NDC) and the opposition New Patriotic Party (NPP) and its presidential contender, Nana Akufo-Addo (3). The election was monitored by the OSCE/ODIHR (6) and triggered violent protests (7).

Timeline.Text: Ghana's presidential and parliamentary elections take place, with the NDC and NPP parties in a close race.
The OSCE/ODIHR deploys short-term observers to monitor the presidential election in Macedonia.
Parliamentary elections are held in Macedonia, with VMRO DPMNE party member Johan Tarculovski winning a seat.
The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe releases a statement on their preliminary findings of the Macedonian parliamentary elections.
Austrian Foreign Minister Sebastian Kurz makes a declaration regarding citizenship for persecuted persons and their descendants.
The UK Parliament releases a list of by-elections that have taken place in the 2015-2017 Parliament.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election saw the conservative VMRO-DPMNE party, led by former Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski, win a majority of seats (1,2,4,6,8). However, Gruevski was unable to form a new government and the crisis in Macedonia remained unresolved (3,7,9,10). Despite this, President Gjorge Ivanov asked Gruevski to form a government (5). The election was characterized by allegations of fraud and corruption, including accusations against Gruevski himself (7,10).

Timeline.Text: Nikola Gruevski leads his party VMRO-DPMNE to an early lead in the parliamentary election in Macedonia.
Veteran leader Nikola Gruevski's nationalist VMRO-DPMNE wins 51 out of 120 seats in Macedonia's parliament in a snap poll, and is expected to form a government.
Macedonia's election commission orders a re-run in one polling station, following a complaint from Nikola Gruevski's VMRO-DPMNE party.
Macedonia's political crisis remains unresolved after the resignation of Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski and early elections.
Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov asks Nikola Gruevski to form a new government following the parliamentary election.
The Democratic Union for Integration considers forming a new coalition with Nikola Gruevski's VMRO-DPMNE party.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election was held on December 11, 2016 (2,4,7,10). The main ruling party, VMRO DPMNE, won 51 out of 120 seats in parliament (3,4,5,10). Johan Tarculovski, a war crimes convict, was elected as an MP from this party (1). There were concerns about authoritarianism and a political crisis in the country leading up to the election (2,8). The State Election Commission reported that the conservative coalition won 38.06% of the vote, slightly ahead of the left-leaning coalition (3). The election was also marked by controversy surrounding the election of a Macedonian judge in Strasbourg (6).

Timeline.Text: Macedonians prepare to vote for members of Parliament.
The ruling VMRO-DPMNE party and the opposition Social Democrats both claim victory in the parliamentary elections.
The ruling VMRO-DPMNE party narrowly wins 51 out of 120 seats in Parliament.
The State Election Commission confirms that the ruling party has won the parliamentary elections with 38.06% of the vote.
Johan Tarculovski, a war crimes convict, is elected as a member of the assembly of the Republic of North Macedonia.
The Republic of Macedonia discovers that the two main parties have finished neck and neck in the parliamentary elections.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election was held on December 11 and resulted in the victory of the ruling VMRO DPMNE party (3). The election of the party's candidate, Johan Tarculovski, who was convicted of war crimes, to parliament caused dismay (4). The election also saw the resignation of Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski (7). The early elections were mediated by the US and EU (6) and were held in an effort to resolve an 18-month-long crisis (5). However, the results left the crisis unresolved (7). The election also raised concerns about authoritarianism in Macedonia (8) and the potential for electoral fraud due to an outdated census (5). Talks to form a new government coalition were ongoing after the election (9).

Timeline.Text: Johan Tarculovski, a convicted war criminal, is nominated as a candidate in the upcoming parliamentary elections.
The election of Jovan Ilievski, Macedonia's chief prosecutor for organized crime, as the country's judge at the European Court of Human Rights causes concern.
Macedonia's nationalistic ruling party wins the parliamentary elections.
Johan Tarculovski, a convicted war criminal, is elected as an MP from the ruling party.
The parliamentary elections fail to resolve the ongoing political crisis in Macedonia.
Negotiations continue for the formation of a new government coalition following the parliamentary elections.
Concerns are raised about potential electoral fraud in the parliamentary elections due to the lack of an up-to-date census.
The close results of the parliamentary elections highlight the ongoing political divisions and authoritarianism in Macedonia.
Early parliamentary elections are scheduled for December 11 in an effort to resolve the country's political crisis.
The conservative party wins a fragile majority in the parliamentary elections.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Macedonian parliamentary election was held on December 11, 2016 (4). The ruling party, VMRO-DPMNE, declared victory (5,6,16) and won 51 seats in the parliament, while the opposition party, SDSM, won 49 seats (16). The election was preceded by a motion to contest its legality due to uneven size of electoral districts (18). This was the fourth successive parliament that failed to run its full four-year term (19). The preliminary voter turnout was estimated to be 74.16% (17).

Timeline.Text: Macedonia holds its parliamentary elections, with both the ruling VMRO-DPMNE party and the opposition Social Democratic Union claiming victory.
The Macedonian elections end in a virtual tie between the two main parties.
The conservative VMRO-DPMNE party wins a narrow victory in the rerun elections in a small village.
The newly elected MPs in Macedonia are handed their certificates by the State Election Commission.
The Macedonian parliament reopens with the newly elected MPs.
The population of the USA as of January 2016 was estimated to be 323,025,335 people.
A small Macedonian party poses a legal challenge to the upcoming elections, citing uneven size of the electoral districts.
Preliminary results indicate that 74.16% of eligible voters in Minnesota voted in the 2016 US presidential election.
Macedonia's Constitutional Court receives a motion contesting the legality of the upcoming elections.
The USA is the world's third most populated country.
Bulgaria's new president calls for snap elections on March 26.
